content: The Energy Efficient Government Technology Act, also known as the Energy Efficient and Energy-Saving Information and Communications Technologies Act, aims to promote energy-efficient technologies in government operations. The National Energy Conservation Policy Act is amended to include a Federal Implementation Strategy for Energy-Efficient and Energy-Saving Information and Communications Technologies, requiring collaboration between Federal agencies and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. The National Energy Conservation Policy Act is amended to include a Federal Implementation Strategy for Energy-Efficient and Energy-Saving Information and Communications Technologies. Federal agencies collaborate with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to develop flexible, cost-effective strategies based on agency requirements and missions. The Federal agencies are required to consider information and communications technologies (ICT) and related infrastructure and practices, such as advanced metering infrastructure, ICT services and products, efficient data center strategies, and power management. The Federal agencies must consider ICT and related infrastructure, such as advanced metering infrastructure, efficient data center strategies, and power management. They should also focus on building information modeling, secure telework tools, and travel substitution tools to increase efficiency and savings. Performance goals need to be established within 180 days of the enactment of this subsection. The Director, in consultation with the Secretary, will establish performance goals for evaluating Federal agencies' efforts in improving energy-efficient ICT systems and practices, including specifications for data center operators to make informed energy decisions. Performance goals will measure information technology costs over a specific time period of 3 to 5 years and cost savings attained via energy-efficient solutions. The Director will maintain a Governmentwide Data Center Task Force comprised of Federal data center program managers, facilities managers, and sustainability officers to provide a complete picture of all costs and savings, including energy costs and savings. The task force members are responsible for sharing progress towards agency and Federal energy efficiency goals and exchanging best practices with the private sector. Each Federal agency must include reports on their energy efficiency efforts.
